verses.verse: And I became very angry when I heard their outcry and these words.

After serious thought, I rebuked the nobles and rulers, and said to them, ((Ex. 22:25; Lev. 25:36; Deut. 23:19, 20); Ezek. 22:12) “Each of you is exacting usury from his brother.” So I called a great assembly against them.

And I said to them, “According to our ability we have (Lev. 25:48) redeemed our Jewish brethren who were sold to the nations. Now indeed, will you even sell your brethren? Or should they be sold to us?” Then they were silenced and found nothing to say.
Then I said, “What you are doing is not good. Should you not walk (Lev. 25:36) in the fear of our God (2 Sam. 12:14; Rom. 2:24; (1 Pet. 2:12)) because of the reproach of the nations, our enemies?
I also, with my brethren and my servants, am lending them money and grain. Please, let us stop this usury!

Restore now to them, even this day, their lands, their vineyards, their olive groves, and their houses, also a hundredth of the money and the grain, the new wine and the oil, that you have charged them.”

So they said, “We will restore it, and will require nothing from them; we will do as you say.” Then I called the priests, (Ezra 10:5; Jer. 34:8, 9) and required an oath from them that they would do according to this promise.

Then (Matt. 10:14; Acts 13:51; 18:6) I shook out the fold of my garment and said, “So may God shake out each man from his house, and from his property, who does not perform this promise. Even thus may he be shaken out and emptied.” And all the assembly said, “Amen!” and praised the LORD. (2 Kin. 23:3) Then the people did according to this promise.

(The Generosity of Nehemiah) Moreover, from the time that I was appointed to be their governor in the land of Judah, from the twentieth year (Neh. 2:1; 13:6) until the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes, twelve years, neither I nor my brothers ((1 Cor. 9:4-15)) ate the governor’s provisions.

But the former governors who were before me laid burdens on the people, and took from them bread and wine, besides forty shekels of silver. Yes, even their servants bore rule over the people, but (2 Cor. 11:9; 12:13) I did not do so, because of the (Neh. 5:9) fear of God.
Indeed, I also continued the (Neh. 4:1; 6:1) work on this wall, and we did not buy any land. All my servants were gathered there for the work.
And (2 Sam. 9:7; 1 Kin. 18:19) at my table were one hundred and fifty Jews and rulers, besides those who came to us from the nations around us.

Now that (1 Kin. 4:22) which was prepared daily was one ox and six choice sheep. Also fowl were prepared for me, and once every ten days an abundance of all kinds of wine. Yet in spite of this I (Neh. 5:14, 15) did not demand the governor’s provisions, because the bondage was heavy on this people.
(2 Kin. 20:3; Neh. 13:14, 22, 31) Remember me, my God, for good, according to all that I have done for this people.

(Conspiracy Against Nehemiah) Now it happened (Neh. 2:10, 19; 4:1, 7; 13:28) when Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arab, and the rest of our enemies heard that I had rebuilt the wall, and that there were no breaks left in it (Neh. 3:1, 3) (though at that time I had not hung the doors in the gates),

that Sanballat and Geshem (Prov. 26:24, 25) sent to me, saying, “Come, let us meet together among the villages in the plain of (1 Chr. 8:12; Neh. 11:35) Ono.” But they (Ps. 37:12, 32) thought to do me harm.
So I sent messengers to them, saying, “I am doing a great work, so that I cannot come down. Why should the work cease while I leave it and go down to you?”
But they sent me this message four times, and I answered them in the same manner.
Then Sanballat sent his servant to me as before, the fifth time, with an open letter in his hand.
